evaluation.message: I need a clean snapshot of my liquidity this quarter. The kids have been “simplifying” accounts, and I want to see the whole picture, not just the sanitized dashboard my family office pushes me.
evaluation.response:
Got it. Let’s build an independent, whole‑of‑house liquidity snapshot for this quarter that doesn’t rely on your family office’s filters.

What you’ll get
- One-page roll-up: total available liquidity by 0/5/30/90-day buckets and by currency.
- Net free liquidity after scheduled obligations this quarter.
- Breakout by entity and account; what’s restricted/pledged; undrawn committed credit.
- Upcoming capital calls/distributions, tax and debt service, and any gaps.
- Exceptions list: missing statements, unexplained transfers, changed signers/permissions.

Fast path (48–72 hours)
1) Freeze perimeter and ensure independent access
- Set or confirm read‑only credentials for every bank/brokerage; turn on MFA.
- Ask each institution for a “relationship/household account listing” including closed accounts for the last 24 months and signatory/online-user entitlements.
- Remove anyone else’s admin rights where not needed; keep their access view‑only.

2) Collect source data (as-of today and YTD)
- Banks/brokerages: current and available balances, sweep/money market tickers, settlement dates, held amounts, pledged/margin flags.
- Cash equivalents: MMFs (gov vs prime), T‑bills, CDs/term deposits with maturity/early‑withdrawal penalties.
- Credit: undrawn committed lines (SBL/margin, LOC/HELOC), amounts drawn, advance rates, covenants, collateral, cross‑default/pledge details.
- Private funds: uncalled commitments and any noticed capital calls/distributions this quarter; notice and settlement periods; gates.
- Obligations this quarter: estimated taxes, loan amortization/bullet payments, payroll/household, tuition, insurance, philanthropy, large planned purchases, recurring transfers.
- FX: non‑USD balances and known FX needs.

3) Reconcile and find anything missing
- Compare this year’s institution list to last year’s 1099s/K‑1s and prior statements.
- Pull your credit reports to surface new credit lines and authorized users.
- Scan 6–12 months of bank wires/ACH for transfers to institutions not on your list; trace those.
- Brokerage ACATS/DTC transfer reports for outbound/inbound assets.
- Ask the family office for: complete account inventory (all entities), raw holdings/balances CSVs (no filters), capital call/distribution schedule, and an entitlements audit. Keep this as a cross‑check, not a primary source.

4) Classify liquidity and compute availability
- Tier 0 (same‑day): bank available cash, government MMFs, T‑bills maturing within 5 business days.
- Tier 1 (T+1–T+5): settlement cash, prime MMFs, T‑bills/notes within 30 days, CDs with modest penalties.
- Tier 2 (≤90 days): other CDs/term deposits, short‑bond funds, private funds with quarterly liquidity and no gates.
- Committed undrawn credit: haircut by advance rate (e.g., SBL 70–90%, HELOC per limit/covenant).
- Exclude or haircut: pledged/restricted, escrow, collateral accounts; any funds with gates/suspensions.
- Convert to base currency at spot mid (note FX risk if you’ll need to convert).

5) Net free liquidity (this quarter)
Net free liquidity = Available 0–30 day cash/cash‑equivalents + conservative share of 31–90 day + safe portion of undrawn committed credit − scheduled obligations (taxes, debt service, capital calls, recurring) + scheduled inflows (salary, fund distributions, maturities).

6) Ongoing, independent view
- Stand up your own read‑only aggregation (e.g., Plaid/Yodlee -> a private sheet/database you control) or direct CSV/OFX pulls monthly.
- Monthly reconciliation checklist; change log for signers/permissions; exception report for new accounts or large transfers.

Minimal data I need from you to start
- Snapshot date and base currency.
- List of entities you want included (personal, trusts, LLCs/LPs, foundation).
- Latest statements or CSVs for: all bank/brokerage accounts; any LOC/SBL/HELOC; private fund capital account statements and notice letters.
- Known obligations this quarter (amounts/dates) and any expected distributions.
- Any accounts you suspect were “simplified” or moved; names of institutions likely involved.

If you’d like, I can give you a clean spreadsheet template you or an assistant can populate. Columns:
- Entity | Institution | Account name/last4 | Currency | Balance date | Ledger balance | Available balance | Liquidity tier (0/1/2) | Settlement days | Restricted/pledged (Y/N) | Notes | Undrawn credit | Advance rate | Callable/notice days | FX needs (Y/N)
- Obligations: Counterparty | Amount | Currency | Due date | Category (tax, debt, payroll, capital call, other)
- Inflows: Source | Amount | Currency | Expected date | Certainty (firm/likely/speculative)

Quick red‑flags to check now
- Any accounts where you’re not a primary owner/signatory.
- New authorized users or changed transfer limits.
- Margin or SBL liens on accounts labeled as “cash.”
- Private funds switched from government to prime MMFs for cash management.
- LOC covenants tied to market values that could reduce availability.

Tell me how you want to proceed: share the basics above and I’ll outline the totals and any gaps immediately, then we’ll fill in details as statements come in.
